description: Borrowed from Middle French audible, from Late Latin audibilis, from Latin audire (“to hear”).

adjectives.description: audible (comparative more audible, superlative most audible)

entries.meaning: (American football) The act of or an instance of changing the play at the line of scrimmage by yelling out a new one.
examples: The audible changed the play to a run.

verbs.description: audible (third-person singular simple present audibles, present participle audibling, simple past and past participle audibled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, American football) To change the play at the line of scrimmage by yelling out a new one.
examples: The quarterback audibled after seeing the defensive formation.
